title: Will Venezuela or its state-owned oil company Petroleos de Venezuela SA (PDVSA) default on any of its foreign debt before 1 February 2017?
preds: No movement on this front so far...one day to go :)
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Passage of time, now less than 0.5% chance
1-month TFIF ~3%, all quiet on the Venezuelan front..
There are no payments due on Venezuelan or PDVSA debt between now and Feb 1
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Venezuela's minimum wage, including food subsidies, is rising to 104,358 bolivars a month, or $31 a month, according to the unofficial exchange rate on 
Venezuelan currency exchange causing chaos
The minimum wage was previously increased in October, when the government raised it 40%.
Exorbitant food prices and massive shortages of food and medicine have plagued Venezuelans for years, and the situation worsened in 2016. Inflation in Venezuela is expected to be 1,660% in 2017, according to the International Monetary Fund.
Unless PEOTUS DJT targets Venezuela/PDVSA with a Tweet or mention during inauguration that would encourage a default, it appears unlikely.

1-month TFIF ~5.5%, Brent Crude still in a bullish 1-2 month condition.

Venezuela will default within the next 2 years.  But not that soon.

Unlikely to occur in the next 30 days if it hasn't happened yet.
Drip drip drip. Lowering to zero... passage of time. There's still a chance this could happen, but there's a much bigger chance it'll drag out more than a month...probably more.

COMMENT:  I think that these excerpts sum up the situation.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Dropping substantially as they seem up to date and from what I understand they have a month grace so if up to date at end December then they probably ok to 1st Feb.. are any payments due before end 2016?

Top forecasters I follow (TFIF) averaging ~14% over last month + technical breakout/strength in crude oil markets = Venezuela's VIPs holding on for a a few more months. All bets are off, however, as rates rise and oil prices decline from Q2 2017..

It is possible PDVSA could pay (in Dec) the earlier missed Nov payments, but with the new demonetization exercise and only USD10Bn of reserves, it is a close probability event. If it misses the Dec schedule, technical default becomes a full-fledged default. Oil price rise above 55 a barrel since the OPEC production cuts will possibly give sufficient cash to tide over in the short-term. So higher probability of payment, but risk remains the Dec (Nov missed) repayment
Venezuela has not defaulted on any of its debts till now
As far as I can tell by the news, the late payment by PDVSA has been resolved.  There aren't many payments due between now and Feb 1st.
With higher oil prices and only 7 weeks before this forecast closes PDVSA will probable be able to just about hold off default.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Increasing price of oil will decrease chance of default.

Reducing after discussions with a sovereign analyst.  He confirmed payments have been made and that without removal of Maduro, they will continue to fulfill debt obligations (his opinion).  In addition, a PDVSA default would be incredibly complex and something no matter who's in control would want to avoid.
Moving this up a bit with the recent debt rating cut.

Venezuela's currency has been devaluating 5-10% DAILY for the past weeks. How this affects reserves and thus payments before Feb is unclear, but no high hopes of avoiding default shortly after. The black market rate for the Bolivar is to surpass 3,000/dollar today, an economic collapse that under any other circumstances...

Unlikely. A swap has just occurred, leaving Venezuela enough room to pay its November 2016 installments. The next installments for PdVSA debt are due in April, so any default before that is unlikely, bar a strong downward pressure on the bolÃ­var.

With more talks scheduled the odds of Maduro staying in power long enough look better.
They can' t even afford the paper toilet

PDVSA is obviously has serious cash flow problems. If it can't pay port fees and the ports are refusing services how does it earn revenue? There seem to be lots of complicated interlinked debt obligations any one of which could trigger a technical default. If no one trusts you enough to give you a few dollars credit any unpaid bill could be the straw that breaks the camels back.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.

PDVSA manages its liquidity in part from internal cash flows, but the government’s fiscal demands and control over foreign exchange, along with the difficulty in obtaining long-term financing, mean it will have to continue to seek alternative funding sources in the shorter-term markets with frequent rollovers and higher refinancing risk. PDVSA posted $13.1 billion in cash from operations in 2015 (including Moody’s adjustments). For 2016, we expect cash generation to decline as a consequence of lower Brent prices as compared to the $52 per barrel average in 2015. This is credit negative considering the $15 billion in capital expenditures planned for the year (down from an average of $23 billion in 2012-14), as per our expectations. PDVSA’s cash balance was roughly $5.8 billion as of December, 2015 but has presumably declined with the lower oil price in the first part of the year and limited access to external financing.
http://blogs.barrons.com/emergingmarketsdaily/2016/10/28/bond-swap-for-venezuelas-pdvsa-delays-default-risk-for-now/

COMMENT:  I believe there is another payment coming up in November. Thanks to @seamusfag for the link that shows a big drop in the PDSVA bonds.

Oct 28 Venezuelan state oil company PDVSA has paid down its $1 billion 2016 bond that matured on Friday, the company said in a statement, pushing the OPEC nation's international reserves to their lowest level in 20 years.

It seems like the PDVSA bond swap will not qualify as default under the terms of the question and it has given the company a little more breathing room over the next year.  The current government is hoping that oil prices will continue to rebound over the next year enough to keep the company and the government solvent.  The fact that the debt which was exchanged was due in April and November of next year is a signal that they have the assets to continue making payments their scheduled bond payments for the next 6 months or so, though it gets more murky after that.  Presumably the deal pushes any chance of default into 2018, though this is surely dependent on the price of oil.

COMMENT:  I'm not surprised!
Payment in local currency will tigger a default

Venezuela is in a credit crunch, which is a very tight squeeze in a short timespan. Factor in crazy prices (something like 800% inflation), and it is likely that the rollover won't be sufficient to cover the next payments. Creditors disappear, then default will happen fast.

The sprawling firm’s “cash flow will be very complicated next year” if the offer to replace debt maturing in 2017 with bonds maturing years later doesn’t go through, he said.

Corrected to reflect that restructuring of debts will not count as a default (as far as this forecast is concerned, although I guess it might as far as the markets are concerned).

If the swap is completed the revised repayments due in November 2016 reduces by $2 billion. I would assume that if it does not take place default could occur then. As acceptance had been substantially less than the 50% required by 6 Oct, I read this as meaning well short of $3.5 billion. It is not clear to me why those who had not accepted by 6 Oct would accept by 12 Oct. It is still not 100% clear that even if the swap takes place that it will not be considered a default.
Going up to consensus on low investor interest in the swaps. Deadline for swaps extended again.

I'm moving 35% to 37% because I feel like I already had this risk priced in, but some of you down at zero might want to think about whether you should price in a slight chance here. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-10-07/pdvsa-extends-debt-swap-deadline-on-low-bondholder-participation

Credit default swaps [1] and bond prices [2] continue to rally in the wake of news on the bond swap program [3][4].  The goal of the swap program seems to be to push the possibility of default out farther into the future in the hopes that oil prices will rise sufficiently to avoid default altogether.  This is good news overall, but it is not entirely encouraging given that the government had to offer better terms than their original bid in order to get enough traders to start buying in, and it might be a sign that they are having trouble putting together enough cash for their bond payments.  Nevertheless, the markets are implying that default risk has decreased.
"Overcorrection" of previous prediction, in face of swaps news.
Looks like swaps will do the trick.  The operative word there is "trick."

Petroleos de Venezuela SA wants investors to swap $7 billion of bonds maturing in April and November next year for new 8.5 percent notes with payments staggered over the next four years. If the participation rate is 50 percent or higher, that would materially reduce the risk of the sovereign defaulting in the next 12 months by avoiding a disorderly default from PDVSA, which has more near-term maturities than Venezuela, Moody’s said.

PDVSA changed its debt swap terms, which should lower the chances of a technical default, which is why I've once again dropped my forecast here (40% ---> 35%). At the same time, the fact they've needed to change the terms so radically does suggest a greater cash flow urgency than they've let on. As I've stressed in previous comments, there is no collective action clause within the PDVSA debt, which means that even if debt is restructured, a single holdout who is not paid will lead to a technical default. The Venezuelan govt has insisted they will pay everyone and I think they intend to do so, but if they are not capable due to cash flow (because not enough debt holders take the deal), it could occur.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.

There are numerous news stories detailing the failing economy in general. The Reuters story below refers to PDVSA offering drilling contracts where the drillers are being asked to pay $700m to drill and receiving oil. The Bloomberg story suggests that the debt Swap being proposed (swapping state debts due in April and November 2017 for notes staggering repayment over the next 4 years) will probably itself be defined as a default. If it is then presumably this question will be answered as "yes" before 1 Feb.  From reading other forecasters comments it seems they understand that this swap reduces the likelihood of a default, my reading is that the swap itself is a default. Presumably if you volunteer to swap its not a default, if you are forced to swap it is a default.

Dropping back down to 40 but still keeping relatively high. The past week has suggested a lot of govt money has moved in to Venezuela bonds, which suggests repayment. At the same time, several ratings agencies have signaled they could list Venezuela as having technically defaulted if the bond swap conditions are not within a certain set of parameters. This will leave it up to the judges here to decide whether that counts as a default.

PDVSA bonds do not appear to be reacting much to latest news, bit more volatile but no big fall in price.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Moving 30 to 55. Citibank refusal to process payments means that Venezuela could fall into a technical default if it cannot find another payment provider. Citibank's un-cited reasoning allegedly includes the fact that they worry processing bond payments may violate OFAC rules, something other banks are not going to want to mess with. This makes a technical default (and a Venezuelan-optional default blamed on technical reasons) more likely in the short term. Will monitor the payment issue to see if I can drop this back down below the 50% mark.
Citi Bank has just announced that it will no longer process bond repayments. Risk of default has increased significantly
Analysts stil split on default, however markets aren't really showing a big sell-off of venezulian debt [1]... Only dropping 2% or so in recent days.

Bolivar and CB reserves have stabilised (http://venezuelaecon.com/) and PDVSA looks like it will successfully tender new drilling rights (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-pdvsa-contract-exclusive-idUSKCN1112D7). Either government would make maintaining payments to foreign creditors a (the) economic priority. Many options exist before a hard default became likely. We are essentially asking here for the likelihood of a catastrophic breakdown in the Venezuelan nation state.
Restructuring with China is very possible, oil prices have risen and Maduro appears to be motivated and sincere about servicing debt. The biggest wild card may be how long Maduro stays in power.

New help from Iran, outlined in recent visit of Tehran FM to Caracas will include financial support for economy.  Link. http://www.cnbrlyc.com/2016/08/27/maduro-says-venezuela-iran-hold-talks-on-oil-price-stability.html

According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Seems more likely than not, since Maduro don't seem too fond of capitalist international economies and Venezuela's economic crisis might bring up the need to allocate resources for minimizing the risk of civil rebellion.

October and November remain the biggest test.  The Maduro government has shown determination to make full payments, and October PDVSA bonds are trading at close to full value: http://www.boerse-berlin.com/index.php/Bonds?isin=XS0460546798 .  Venezuela likely still has the oil and gold reserves necessary to make payments, so the main risk remains political.  Maduro's approval rating is less than 25% ( http://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKCN10Q28M) among shortages of basic goods and extremely high inflation.  If he stays in power Venezuela is likely to continue to make debt payments as long as they have the liquidity to do so.  If he is somehow removed from power the new government would likely use default to restructure their debt.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

The oil prices and revenues will continue to be quite low respect to what is needed by the extremely corrupt regime to survive, so there is higher chance of foreign debt default before 1 February 2017.
word is they will probably be able to run a restructuring scam a couple of times first before they actually go into default.  still, this is easier for the sovereign debt than for the SOE.

Using this bond as my proxy.

The market implied probability of default for PDVSA bonds to 1 Feb 2017 is 31.37% at present. This is based on Credit Default Swap prices as they stand today (9 Aug 16). (For those for are into the technical details, I have used a recovery expectation of 12.5% - half the normal rate - given that it would difficult to enforce creditor rights in Venezuela. The standard 1yr CDS contract is based on 25% up front and a running spread of 6,700bp on top).
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
On one hand, the current oil price trajectory doesn't bode well for Venezuela. 2 forces underpin the reason why Venezuela or PDVSA have quite a high probability of defaulting.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Venezuela has been in extreme financial peril for at least a year now, but there's some chance another country may help and there's some chance this will drag out. 
Let's assume 80% probability that they will not be rescued and that they will default within the next 2 or 3 years. 
Assume that is split into 6-month time-frames (weighting closer periods): [ 30%, 20%, 10%, 10%, 5%, 5%]
With  6 months to go till the end of this question, I'm going to assume about a 30% chance they'll default by the end...and reduce a bit each month.
Looks like paying off debt is a priority for the Venezuelan govt to get access to add'l funding [1]

Venezuelan Gov't and economy in a tailspin [1] with Gov't having taken control of oil company's operations from private / commercial oversight.  Venezuelan oil production is plummeting (currently at 13 years low [2]) with rolling blackouts/brownouts contributing to low production.
Enough reserves of gold and oil.

I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

per @Rene article (http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-04/venezuela-refuses-to-default-few-people-seem-to-understand-why) , the markets say most likely and 3 reasons why not.  Trusting the article completely "The government is due to make $1.5 billion in foreign debt payments in the second half of this year. Include PDVSAâ€™s tab and the figure swells to $5.8 billion."  This is half their current "hard currency reserves down to just $12 billion".  I am assuming that they'll pay this years.  I imagine there to be some tricky snicky payment in Jan that will cause much chin scratching if oil goes back down (reason 1), or if whoever is getting these returns changes side etc (reason 2 as per article). The question is probably when not if Venezuela/PDVSA will default but whether they default between now and the deadline depends on oil and gold prices. Looking at sites like Barrons's and The Economist there are estimates of a default this year from 45-76%. Probably the biggest risk are the $2-3 Bn PDVSA repayments this autumn and they are trading at 56c on the dollar. The oil price is up about 70% since some of the direst predictions were made. They have sold approx 1/3 of their gold since repatriating it (which is alarmingly fast) but that leaves 2/3, currently valued at $12bn and would seem to be enough to push this issue into next year at least. They can probably sell PDVSA assets in the US like parts of Citgo to raise cash and either as sovereign or PDVSA they could probably re-negotiate terms with China although they may regret what they have to give up long term in return.

Venezuela’s gold reserves have plunged to their lowest level on record after it sold $1.7bn of the precious metal in the first quarter of the year to repay debts. The country is grappling with an economic crisis that has left it struggling to feed its population.
The Opec member’s gold reserves have dropped almost a third over the past year and it sold over 40 tonnes in February and March, according to IMF data. Gold now makes up almost 70 per cent of the country’s total reserves, which fell to a low of $12.1bn last week.
http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/c674defa-2281-11e6-aa98-db1e01fabc0c.html#axzz49nPWaugX

Venezuela has 12.1 b in total reserves, 70% (8.5 b) in gold reportedly the 16th largest national reserve. FT (5/26) reports that Chavez turned most of the reserves to gold and brought it back to Caracas in 2011.  The gold price is up 15% so far during 2016.

Moody's had downgraded them to Caa3 and  are negative in their future. They began in 2001 with an A3 rating, went into a lower rating since then, had one upgrade in 2004 and further downgraded after that one bounce. Borrowing on the market will exacerbate their debt in a low oil economy that will not increase their rating, especially as Saudi Arabia and other OPEC members cannot agree on boosting oil, which was why there is no agreement to limit production; by default or design it weakened Saudi Arabia's competitors, including Iran, and Venezuela is collateral damage of it. Venezuela is an oil dependent exporter and does not have the funds to continue supporting an industry that is not producing revenue for them.
Venezuela is reported to be selling its gold reserve to face the crisis.

strapped Venezuela’s move to slash imports to a 12-year low may allow it to avoid a default this year but will almost certainly exacerbate shortages of everything from medicine to toilet paper.
The Andean nation will cut purchases of overseas goods to about $20 billion from $37 billion in 2015, Vice President for Economic Policy Miguel Perez Abad said last week. 
The reduction means Venezuela will have enough cash to honor its bond payments in 2016, according to Eurasia Group and EMSO Asset Management. Eurasia had predicted the country could halt debt payments this year in the face of low oil prices and the worst recession in decades. Swaps traders now put the chances Venezuela will default over the following year at 63 percent, down from 83 percent in February. But while chopping imports is bolstering the country’s ability to pay debt, it’s making life harder for Venezuelans contending with empty supermarket shelves and the world’s fastest inflation, forecast to rise to close to 500 percent this year by the International Monetary Fund.

Oil prices are stabilizing, but massive mismanagement isn't.  Not quite a tossup, but not a gimme.

Oil prices may recover sooner or later if Iran joins the freeze, as seems likely to happen some time in the next sometime--and of course assuming US producers don't ramp up quickly.  However, Maduro is clearly fully capable of running Venezuela into the ground at any oil price level. So I did a fair bit of reading before deciding to answer this question. Basically the black and white situation is something like this. 2016 will see Venezuela pay around $10bn of debt. Numbers are not very clear but this is the ballpark. Now reserves (liquid) it seems are about $13bn. However, the CAD deficit is somewhere close to $20bn for the year. Now the math is obviously gone nuts. So a default is very very likely. Unless, oil recovers, and fast. Or the government changes its socialist policies, fast. Neither looks likely to me. It's a sad state of affairs, and a sad situation. But honestly, with CDS itself trading north of 60%, think the default is more than priced in, and expected. This is of course, over and above a 26-30% debt yield + recent bond issuances of deep discount bonds, that got sold at a third of their parity.

The US has since 2005 implemented several policies (promotion of blending petrol with ethanol, promoting the use of more fuel efficient vehicles) that are reducing its demand. Current economic climates in both Europe and China are leading to less demand. Venezuelas last payment of $1.5billion was in gold, which the appears to not have enough to repay all debts.

Venezuela will continue to sell gold reserves and may make it past the Feb 2017 date but the default will come soon thereafter. The country will not have any electrical power soon and oil prices will continue to be below the level needed to cover production costs and debt service so a complete implosion is inevitable

Yes, as the economy is now in full contraction evidenced by the fact that a 2-day workweek was imposed and the central bank in Caracas has no longer enough money to print new money ... these are anecdotal proofs that the economy is in full recession and that the income from PVDSA is insufficient to cover debt service requirements.

Venezuela's - and, by extension, PDVSA's - default probability is a function of both their ability and willingness to pay.  To be clear, this is true of any sovereign debtor, or any debtor generally.  Venezuela's situation is perhaps unique among sovereigns, however, in that its willingness to pay seems to far outstrip its ability to pay.  Contrast this situation to Argentina under CFK; despite having more than sufficient resources to pay the holdouts - especially once additional hard currency funds that could be raised via capital markets are considered - CFK chose to wage a decade long war to avoid making good on its obligations.  So, let's take each component in turn
increasing +10, and providing just a little more gasoline for the fire...
"Restructuring of debt will not count as a default."
Even with high oil prices, Venezuela's economy was low-performing.  Oil prices may go up, but Venezuela needs oil to be somewhere around $100/barrel to sustain its economy.

This week Venezuela paid up US$ 199.6 million in interest for its 2019 and 2024 sovereign bonds. In 2016 and 2017 the nation and state oil company PDVSA must still repay US$ 9.6 billion, of which US$ 8.1 billion pertain to PDVSA. President Nicolas Maduro has said Venezuela has paid out “US$ 30 billion in debt, a powerful amount”, and denies any default projections. I am revising my forecast up because I originally thought it was referring to just PDVSA (as I learned in school, reading to fast and missing important little words like "or" can be devastating).  Okay, now thinking about either or does raise my forecast because I believe its a low probability for PDVSA.  I still believe there is a strong preference to continue to live up to the debt obligations.  It seems that the government feels its a strike against the socialist foundation that was set up by the still very popular Chavez.  Its as if Chavez was still in power this would not be the situation but Maduro was the hand picked successor -- so, they continue to hope.  Clearly things are very bad in most of the country but the stalemate continues between congress and the president and I don't see any upcoming debt maturities that might create a significant event.  The oil revenue continues to roll in -- not enough to cover the whole socialist bill but enough to muddle along.  So my forecast is half of the probability to default because of the lack of refinancing needs in the next 12 months and the governments preference to pay.

There are signs of the government getting its problems sorted out. With stalemate between President and Parliament, and a clueless government, low oil income, few international friends etc. a last throw by the President could be to default and blame everyone else (speculators, capitalists, the US) then leave office and let someone else deal with it.

Lack of Collective Action Clauses, location of assets and impact on the country makes this a non-story in my book.  Hype by traders as opposed to a sound economic concern.  Yes the financials look bad but the case for default over creative financing weighs heavily in favor of financing the debt, which is not due anyway until Q4.

As a country needing allies, it will raise hell to keep afloat -- even go as far (sic) as inviting (moderate) internal and external cooperation. Maybe even ask China Russia for help (in dire need, support-able countries want to have a dangling partner on US's doorstep ..?).
Nevertheless, society (and the economy as part of that) is stressed so some form of 'revolution' may result in balance sheets being cleaned just to force creditors' hands.

I think that is the high likelihood at current oil prices.  For that not to happen would need an X factor or 2 like: 1) Significant step up of Chinese lending programs or from other int'l entities, 2) large rise in oil prices, 3) imports cut again massively (already running very bare bones), 4) real fx adjustments that attract capital very rapidly.

There will certainly be a default unless Maduro is willing to crank out VEFs until they are as useless as VEBs or the old Zimbabwe trash.  He may be; no one has so far accused him of excessive contact with reality.  Big question is when.  I think sooner than later.

The socialist government of President Maduro was sent a strong message in December 2015 but all that has transpired is greater polarization as he tries to hang on to power.  He weakened the legislative branch in an effort to slow a reform agenda.  Although transparency is non-existent, I don't believe the current price of oil is delivering the required amount to run the socialist economy.  Venezuelans are being impacted in their daily lives -- shortages of basic products and the erosion of disposable incomes.  Either oil prices have to rise or there has to be a cut back.

There seems to be deep structural corruption issues - the Swiss banks handing over records doesn't happen every day - and it does not seem like the price of oil is increasing at a rate that would allow Petroleos de Venezuela SA to overcome its issues or that the political situation in Venezuela will become more stable any time soon. My uncertainty stems from the timeline - I think it may take longer than a year for this to happen - but I think it is likely to happen.
will be bailed out by Russia

I think that is the high likelihood at current oil prices.  For that not to happen would need an X factor or 2 like: 1) Significant step up of Chinese lending programs or from other int'l entities, 2) large rise in oil prices, 3) imports cut again massively (already running very bare bones), 4) real fx adjustments that attract capital very rapidly.

Global appetite for default is minimal. I think it is more likely that a restructuring plan will be mooted, involving divestments, futures contracts, etc. Also, with political rivalry acute, the pains of default is likely to propel the opposition into power, when in fact, a restructuring plan can alleviate concerns for a while more - at least till the government can consolidate its hold on power. 
Also, with oil looking up, this optimism is likely to be considered by creditors in pushing Venezuela to the wall.  
Still, it is a volatile environment out there. I will consider Moody's ratings for PDVSA, and up it by 15% given the country's political/macroeconomic landscape

I started out out with Annienak on this one, with a slight nod to consensus. I don't know how different this year is from last year. But I notice that a few of the higher predictions involve statements like "it's been a long time coming" or "time to pay the piper", which imply a narrative lens I don't think has good predictive power. This leads me to trend a bit below the consensus. But I am wondering whether a default to some small-time lender we aren't thinking about would count for this, a la @patrickmeehan5. And the financial markets probably know *something*. And another oil fluctuation could bring about desperate measures. It's much easier to think of reasons default would happen than reasons that it wouldn't, but I'll keep a grip on this and settle in at 72.

PDVSA is not a normal company, so normal business rules do not apply. So for example an oil consuming state (China?) that may also be an owner of PDVSA bonds might offer to provide the money to allow PDVSA to avoid default in return for an advanced purchase of oil for delivery in 2017 or 2018. This might make more sense to them than allowing PDVSA to default and having to write down the value of the bonds it holds.

Debt default is worst case scenario for PDVSA therefore all forces capable of preventing such an event will be marshaled.  There are other mitigating factors may delay an inevitable default, including a regression-to-the-mean change in oil prices. It is still unclear whether oils price changes are durable and based on systemic changes in production or shorter term demand shifts.  Additionally, China is likely to attempt to protect its 5bil loan already invested in PDVSA.  PDVSA and Venezuela's finance issues are systemic and structural, and default is likely, however the time horizon of such a default is the primary variable.  It is likely, given historical correlaries, that the Venezuelan government will likely raid all other funding sources before defaulting on debt, thus cutting off foreign investment and the government's ability to fund its operations.  PDVSA has large debt maturities due in 16, 17, and 18 but is likely to make all attempts to push those maturities farther out. Creditors are likely to be amenable to such restructuring as default yields a total loss for the creditor.
semantics: even a late payment would technically trigger a default.

Venezuela seems to be on a path to defaulting on its debt, but it seems that it will have the capacity to pay its debt in 2016 and its first debt payments will not be due until after 2/1/17.  They may restructure the public debt and have the ability to negotiate restructuring on the state run oil company debt provided all parties agree to it.  Oil seems to have stabilized and will give them more money than earlier predicted should it hold at current prices or continue to rise.  There is also political unrest that must be watched as this could have an effect on the stability of the country and its debt.  I will continue to watch the debt repayments that are scheduled in the fall of 2016.  If they show the ability to repay this I will begin to lower my forecast for possible default.

Venezuela remains highly dependent on oil revenues, which account for almost all export earnings, and nearly half of the government’s revenue. The country ended 2015 with an estimated 10% contraction in its GDP, 160% inflation, widespread shortages of consumer goods, and declining central bank international reserves. The International Monetary Fund forecasts that the GDP will shrink another 6% in 2016 and inflation may reach 204%.
Falling oil prices since 2014 have aggravated Venezuela’s economic crisis. Insufficient access to dollars, price controls, and rigid labor regulations have led some US and multinational firms to reduce or shut down their Venezuelan operations. High costs for oil production and state oil company PDVSA’s poor cash flow have slowed investment in the petroleum sector, resulting in a decline in oil production.

THE ECONOMIC & POLITICAL SITUATION IN VENEZUELA

Initial thoughts:
Market is somewhere around 80% likely to default. Good base rate to build off of. Several recent articles has offered contrarian takes as to why default is less likely than the market thinks (mostly because default will be a disaster for a country that needs to export oil). At the same time, the Maduro govt barely scraped by their February payment and there is little relief in site. The Venezuelan government has prioritized debt payments over many other things and that attitude will likely continue. However, they may just run out of money. Foreign reserves, including gold, can only pay for about 8-10 more months of imports at the bare-bones levels.

I am unable to construct a scenario under which they avoid default, beginning with PDVSA, probably this summer.  Renegotiation isn't default, of course, but the hole they are in is pretty deep. And they seem still to be digging.
